results.title: THE 15 BEST Paris Cultural Events (2025)

results.title: The best free things to do in Paris
results.content:
If you're looking for a less crowded dive into Paris’ rich art scene, gallery hopping is where it's at. Forget the packed museums – Paris has over 1000 contemporary art galleries, each offering revolving shows of the biggest artists and up-and-coming talent for free. Wander through the Marais, Belleville, Saint-Germain-des-Prés and even northeast of the Île-de-France and you'll discover everything from cutting-edge contemporary works to street art. [...] Plenty of Paris’ magic emits from its abundant free activities. You can meet the artists of indie-spirited Belleville, visit museums like the Petit Palais and Musée Bourdelle, and cruise the Seine for free on your birthday. For something more offbeat, explore the abandoned railway of La Petite Ceinture, a hidden urban oasis, or dance the night away at drag bingo.

Find out how you can see Paris without breaking the bank using these travel tips. [...] Planning tip:The best way to explore the city’s art galleries is with a guide, like Alexandra Weinress, who organizes bespoke art walks that can be as compact or detailed as you like in either English or French.

Image 27: A large bronze sculpture of a horse in the center of a courtyard with topiary and other statues that's surrounded by red brick archways.

The garden at the Musée Bourdelle. Sylvain Sonnet/Getty Images

11 of the best free things to do in Paris
=========================================

[Rooksana Hossenally](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/authors/rooksana-hossenally)
Apr 12, 2025 • 11 min read

 Share 

![Image 23: People studying in the Oval Room of a Richilieu National Library in Paris, France on October 5, 2022. © agaliza / Getty Images](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2024-06/GettyImages-1434106941.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&w=1440&h=810&fit=crop)

The Oval Room at the Richelieu site of the Bibliothèque Nationale de France. agaliza/Getty Images

[Paris](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris)is a magnet for[visitors](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/first-time-paris) from all over the world, and its[top historic and cultural sights](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/best-things-to-do-in-paris)more than merit the intensity of the attraction. The city's reputation as one of the world’s most expensive places is also well justified. But if you think you need a huge budget to make the most of the capital of [France](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/destinations/france), you'd be wrong.

Plenty of Paris’ magic emits from its abundant free activities. You can meet the artists of indie-spirited Belleville, visit museums like the Petit Palais and Musée Bourdelle, and cruise the Seine for free on your birthday. For something more [offbeat](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/escape-the-obvious-paris-cabaret-crazy-horse-moulin-rouge), explore the abandoned railway of La Petite Ceinture, a hidden urban oasis, or dance the night away at drag bingo.

Find out how you can see Paris without breaking the bank using these travel tips.

1. Do a digital detox at a library that’s not just for literary buffs
---------------------------------------------------------------------

Tiptoeing inside the stillness of the [Oval Room at the Richelieu site](https://www.bnf.fr/en/oval-room)of the Bibliothèque Nationale de France, which was finished in 1932, is like finding a portal to the past. Shelves that rise up to the glass ceiling are stacked with over 20,000 books (many of which date back centuries) and 9000 comic books, all of which are available to visitors. From its ancient scrolls to modern classics, this library is a bibliophile's paradise. Whether you're a history buff, a literature lover or just looking for a cozy corner to get lost in a good book, this is the place to come. Grab a seat and soak in the magic.

 Advertisement 

**Planning tip:**The Oval Room is free and open to all visitors (closed Sundays). It’s located in the historic neighborhood of the [Jardin du Palais Royal](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/louvre-and-les-halles/attractions/jardin-du-palais-royal/a/poi-sig/372471/1322719), which is worth a wander for the gardens and the old boutiques tucked in the arches.

![Image 24: People walking on a path alongside a repurposed railway track lined by trees and bushes.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2024-06/GettyImages-1391994510.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

La Petite Ceinture. UlyssePixel/Getty Images

2. Explore Paris from its abandoned railway
-------------------------------------------

[La Petite Ceinture](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/montparnasse-and-southern-paris/attractions/petite-ceinture-du-15e/a/poi-sig/1486640/1323144)snakes above and below inner Paris for a 30km (19-mile) stretch of green space full of history and some of the city’s best street art. Built over 150 years ago, this abandoned railway – now a refuge for wildlife like foxes, as well as a playground for graffiti artists and urban explorers – is slowly being reclaimed by the city and turned into a promenade similar to [New York’s High Line](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/new-york-city/the-village-chelsea-and-meatpacking-district/attractions/high-line/a/poi-sig/1105837/1320602).

The railway fell out of use completely by 1993, after being replaced by the [Paris metro network](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/getting-around-paris) and motorized vehicles. Today, projects like [Jardins du Ruisseau](https://lesjardinsduruisseau.fr/)are transforming parts of it into an oasis of community gardens, and [La REcyclerie](https://www.larecyclerie.com/) and [Hasard Ludique](https://www.lehasardludique.paris/)are establishing hybrid food and arts hubs inside the former stations.

**Planning tip:** Segments of the railway are closed to the public so look at the [map of open sections](https://www.promeneurs-petiteceinture.paris/guide) before setting off. The guide also outlines itineraries for each section.

![Image 25: People in the ornate rotunda of a museum, with a patterned floor and items suspended from the ceiling.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2024-06/shutterstockeditorial2243248377.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

The Petit Palais. Franck Legros/Shutterstock

3. Brush up on art history at the Petit Palais
----------------------------------------------

Visiting the [Petit Palais](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/champs-elysees-and-grands-boulevards/attractions/petit-palais/a/poi-sig/372705/1322783) in Paris has to be on every art and history enthusiast’s list because its brilliant permanent collection, which spans several centuries, is totally free. Built for the 1900 World Expo, the opulent museum features a semicircular garden, a beautifully decorated arcade and intricate details like wrought iron gates, majestic staircases and stained glass windows, which alone are worth a visit.

The displays trace the classical world and Middle Ages through to the art nouveau and impressionist periods, with masterpieces by Claude Monet and Camille Pissarro. An impressive gallery showcases 19th-century sculptures by artists such as Louis-Ernest Barrias and Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi. Regular temporary exhibitions put a fresh spin on French history through art too (there is a fee for entry to special shows). Make sure to set aside some time for a snack or coffee at the cafe in the circular central courtyard, laid with a blue-and-gold mosaic floor and surrounded by leafy gardens.

**Planning tip:**As with all museums in Paris, the Petit Palais gets quite crowded, so aim to go at opening time to get the huge spaces almost to yourself. [Families with young children](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/paris-with-kids) don’t have to queue – there is a dedicated entrance at the bottom of the stairs to the right.

![Image 26: People walk through a narrow, glass-roofed passageway that is lined by restaurants and shops, some of which have dining tables outside.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2024-06/LPT0218035.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

The Passage des Panoramas. Adrienne Pitts/Lonely Planet

4. Browse in the covered arcades
--------------------------------

Paris’ covered shopping arcades shelter yet another side of the city and its unique history. These passages, dating back to the 18th and 19th centuries, are filled with quirky boutiques, old bookstores and places to eat. Though most were demolished due to the rise of department stores, a handful have survived, primarily in the 2nd, 9th and 10th [arrondissements](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/guide-paris-arrondissements).

 Advertisement 

Notable arcades include the ornate Passage du Grand Cerf; the Galerie Vivienne, with its mosaic floor; and Passage des Panoramas, the oldest arcade, known for its stamp shops and restaurants. Passage Choiseul has literary significance due to its association with writer Louis-Ferdinand Céline; Galerie Vero-Dodat is renowned for its antique stores; and Passage Brady, dubbed Little India for its South Asian eateries, should also be on your list. Each passage is a respite from the city bustle, making them perfect for a leisurely stroll rain or shine.

**Planning tip:**A smattering of excellent restaurants are hidden in these arcades, including [Canard et Champagne](https://www.frenchparadox.paris/), [Racines](https://racinesparis.com/en/racines-2/) and [Astair](https://www.astair.paris/) in the Passage des Panoramas, as well as [Caves Legrand](https://www.caves-legrand.com/) in Galerie Vivienne.

5. Swap blockbuster museums for crowd-free art galleries
--------------------------------------------------------

If you're looking for a less crowded dive into Paris’ rich art scene, gallery hopping is where it's at. Forget the packed museums – Paris has over 1000 contemporary art galleries, each offering revolving shows of the biggest artists and up-and-coming talent for free. Wander through the [Marais](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/destinations/france/paris/marais-and-menilmontant), [Belleville](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/lonely-planet-guide-to-belleville), Saint-Germain-des-Prés and even northeast of the Île-de-France and you'll discover everything from cutting-edge contemporary works to street art.

The Marais probably has the highest concentration of galleries, including must-see[Perrotin](https://www.perrotin.com/exhibitions/current/paris/1), [Thaddeus Ropac](https://ropac.net/about/) (also check out its space in Pantin), [Marian Goodman Gallery](https://www.mariangoodman.com/exhibitions/paris/), [Galerie Nathalie Obadia](https://www.nathalieobadia.com/), [Galleria Continua](https://www.galleriacontinua.com/), [Xippas](https://www.xippas.com/)and [Almine Rech](https://www.alminerech.com/). For photography buffs, [Polka Galerie](https://www.polkagalerie.com/en/home.htm) is the place to be, especially on exhibition opening nights, when it showcases some of the world's top photographers, including Sebastião Salgado. Belleville also brims with over 150 artists who welcome visitors to their workspaces every May for the [Bellville Artists' Open Studios](https://ateliers-artistes-belleville.fr/en/les-portes-ouvertes/edition/). Whether you're a connoisseur or just love to bask in the art world, these galleries give a more laid-back look at Paris’ art scene without having to brave the lines at the big museums.

**Planning tip:**The best way to explore the city’s art galleries is with a guide, like Alexandra Weinress, who organizes [bespoke art walks](https://www.theseenparis.com/about) that can be as compact or detailed as you like in either English or French.

![Image 27: A large bronze sculpture of a horse in the center of a courtyard with topiary and other statues that's surrounded by red brick archways.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2024-06/GettyImages-521070920.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

The garden at the Musée Bourdelle. Sylvain Sonnet/Getty Images

6. Wander a garden of sculptures in an artist’s home
----------------------------------------------------

Nope, it’s not [Auguste Rodin](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/st-germain-and-les-invalides/attractions/musee-rodin/a/poi-sig/372149/1322788)but his assistant Antoine Bourdelle. Later in his life, Bourdelle was a teacher to Alberto Giacometti and a pioneering sculptor in his own right. His dramatic, expressive works bridge the gap between classical and modern art, and he significantly influenced early-20th-century sculpture with his innovative techniques and bold forms. The artist's former atelier and residence have been turned into the [Musée Bourdelle](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/montparnasse-and-southern-paris/attractions/musee-bourdelle/a/poi-sig/372649/1323144), one of the most charming little museums in Paris, and admission to the permanent collection is free.

Bourdelle's monumental bronze masterpieces are scattered among quiet gardens that wrap around several workshop and exhibition spaces. One of the former workshops is now a minimalistic cafe with art deco accents – it's named Rhodia after the artist’s daughter, who also lived here. Tables are laid out in the shade on a big terrace in the summer, as well as inside a lemon-yellow dining room, where you can lunch on ceviche and empanadas made by Latin American restaurant [Isana](https://www.isanaparis.com/).

**Planning tip:**Hidden on a side street just steps from the busy Montparnasse station, the museum is closed on Mondays, and the last entry is at 5:40pm. While you're in the area, climb up the[Tour Montparnasse](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/montparnasse-and-southern-paris/attractions/tour-montparnasse/a/poi-sig/372335/1323144)– it's possibly the ugliest building in the city but it has the most magnificent 360-degree [views of Paris](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/best-views-in-paris). You’re also a seven-minute walk to the historic[Bouillon Chartier Montparnasse](https://www.bouillon-chartier.com/en/bouillon-chartier-montparnasse-en/), a great value restaurant with art nouveau interiors dating back to 1903.

![Image 28: An open-top boat on the Seine river at sunset approaching a bridge that is illuminated.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-04/Shutterstock570700273.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

A ​​bateaux-mouche at sunset. pisaphotography/Shutterstock

7. Celebrate your birthday on the Seine
---------------------------------------

While a cruise on the Seine might get a [few eye rolls from locals](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/essential-tourist-rules-for-paris) or frequent visitors, it’s a truly special way to see the city, no matter how many times you’ve been. Trips vary from simple guided tours to floating dinner cruises and parties, and you usually have to pay for the experience. But if it's your birthday, the [Vedettes de Paris](https://www.vedettesdeparis.fr/) company gifts you an [hour-long guided cruise](https://www.vedettesdeparis.fr/en/good-deals/) on the Seine free of charge. So grab your passport (as proof of your birthday) and head to the office at the port, which is by the[Eiffel Tower](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/eiffel-tower-16e-and-la-defense/attractions/eiffel-tower/a/poi-sig/372147/1322674). You can choose between listening to the tour guide in English or French, or you can grab an audio guide with a wider variety of languages. You'll glide along the glittering water and past some of the city’s most remarkable landmarks, from the [Louvre](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/louvre-and-les-halles/attractions/musee-du-louvre/a/poi-sig/372123/1322719) to the [Musée D’Orsay](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/st-germain-and-les-invalides/attractions/musee-d-orsay/a/poi-sig/372151/1322788) and [Notre Dame](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/guide-to-notre-dame-paris),then back to the Eiffel Tower.

**Planning tip:**It’s not possible to book ahead, so you have to show up on the day (until 6:30pm). You can bring up to two guests, but only the person whose birthday it is gets a free ticket.

![Image 29: Many people are wandering around a galleried flea market, with stalls selling a variety of vintage goods over two floors](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2023-08/shutterstockRF252870904.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

Puces de St-Ouen. gabriel12/Shutterstock

8. Get lost in St-Ouen’s maze of flea markets
---------------------------------------------

The Puces de St-Ouen is a must-visit spot, especially if you love a good treasure hunt. Hailed as one of the largest markets in the world, this sprawling bazaar just outside the city’s northern edge is a vintage lover’s dream. Wind through a [maze of over 15 markets](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/best-markets-in-paris), totaling about 2500 stalls and shops with everything from retro furniture and clothing to rare antiques and collectibles.

What makes the Puces de St-Ouen so special is the lively, eclectic vibe. You can chat with passionate vendors, stumble upon unusual items and soak up the bohemian atmosphere in a fascinating glimpse into Parisian culture and history. And you’re sure to leave with more than just a few fabulous finds.A wooden spiral staircase from an old French mansion, anyone?

**Planning tip:** The best time to go is on Saturday morning from 10am on, when the market in full swing. Half the fun is discovering a spot to eat, either in the markets or on the main artery, rue des Rosiers (the one in St-Ouen, not the Marais, for GPS users). My favorite is [Le Coq d’Or](https://lecoqdor.eatbu.com/), which has been serving excellent couscous for years.

9. Dance the night away at a mini club with cutting-edge acts
-------------------------------------------------------------

Like any capital city, [Paris brims with nightlife venues](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/paris-after-dark-nightlife), each one more expensive than the last – unless you know where to go. If you’re on a [tight budget](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/paris-on-a-budget) and prefer not to splurge on entrance fees, then try [Supersonic](https://supersonic-club.fr/) or[Panic Room](https://panicroomparis.com/), both in Bastille. Not only are they totally free to get into, but they host emerging bands and performers, giving them an edge you don’t usually get in run-of-the-mill nightclubs. At Panic Room (open Wednesday to Saturday), there’s a bar upstairs, while the nightclub is in the basement. Happy hour from 7pm to 10pm includes €7 (US$8) cocktails and €4.50 (US$5) pints of Bud. At the equally industrial-looking Supersonic (open every night), the rock gigs and DJ nights are free to get into before 11pm.

10. Dabble in a spot of drag bingo
----------------------------------

After a [dreamy Sunday](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/things-to-do-in-paris-on-sunday), what could possibly add more cheer to the evening than a bit of free [drag bingo](https://alafolie.paris/events/categories/bingo/)? Every week at the [Parc de la Villette](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/montmartre-and-northern-paris/attractions/parc-de-la-villette/a/poi-sig/372093/1323143), a flamboyant cast leads a cheeky three-hour extravaganza of fun, top-notch pop and dance. It’s probably a good idea to have some grasp of French if you want to join in on the laughs or have a chance to win. Parisians don’t come here for the prizes (an old Tarantino DVD, if you’re lucky) but an atmosphere that’s the perfect remedy to Sunday blues. The show starts at 6pm, but get there at 5pm for a good seat.

![Image 30: Flowers and hedges around paths with a long building with arched windows in the background.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-04/Shutterstock1576324663.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

The gardens at the Grand Trianon at Versailles. VD Image Lab/Shutterstock

11. Find out why Versailles is more than a palace
-------------------------------------------------

The [Château de Versailles](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/versailles/attractions/chateau-de-versailles/a/poi-sig/460039/1320162) isn't just a palace – it's a whole vibe. From the gilded Hall of Mirrors, where kings once presided over their subjects (and raucous parties), to the meticulously manicured gardens with elaborate fountains, to [Marie-Antoinette’s private hamlet](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/versailles/attractions/petit-trianon/a/poi-sig/460049/1320162) away from the court's watchful eye, every corner of Versailles tells a story.

Over 15 million people visit each year, making it one of the most popular attractions in the world. The gardens are free to visit all year round (except during special events), and the whole estate is completely free on the first Sunday of each month from November to March. Get there early as the lines can be long.

**Planning tip:**The suburb of [Versailles](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/versailles), a 45-minute journey out of Paris' center, is known for being just as expensive as the capital, so make sure to [buy something to eat at a bakery](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/best-croissants-in-paris) before arriving, then enjoy it on the lawns in the warmer months. To take in the whole palace, set aside at least [half a day](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/the-best-day-trips-from-paris).

_Rooksana Hossenally is one of the authors of the [Lonely Planet Paris guidebook](https://shop.lonelyplanet.com/products/paris)._

Itâs here that youâll catch much of the art sceneâs latest emerging talent and you wonât need to queue â in fact youâll often get the chance to be alone in a room to take in the works. # Top things to do in Paris

Mar 14, 2025 • 12 min read

![A view of Paris' skyline with the Eiffel Tower prominent in the distance, while a branch of pink tree blossoms dominates the foreground.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2024-06/shutterstockRF390084601.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&w=1440&h=810&fit=crop)

From dining on the Seine in a floating restaurant, to finding your favorite view of the Eiffel Tower, here are the best things to do in Paris. Neirfy/Shutterstock

*Rooksana Hossenally is one of the authors of the [Lonely Planet Paris guidebook](https://shop.lonelyplanet.com/products/paris). Here she shares her suggestions for the best - and most unique - activities to do in Paris.*

Paris has retained its spot as a leading city destination in the world, and itâs not hard to see why. Being a [Paris](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris) local, I may be biased, but the French capital really does have it all, from centuries-old architecture and fascinating history to dynamic food and art and a multicultural population pushing the boundaries of creativity.

What really draws crowds, however, are the things you can only do in Paris. From Michelin-star dining on the River Seine to flea-market shopping on the outskirts of the city, here are some of the top things to do on your next visit to Paris.

![Some people are standing out on the deck of the Ducasse sur Seine, a floating restaurant, as it glides down the River Seine at dusk.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2024-06/shutterstockeditorial2367601781.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

## 1. Have dinner on the Seine imagined by Michelin-star chefs

The range of dinner cruises on the Seine is overwhelming, and it can be hard to choose between them. If you want to splash out, failsafe options include the floating restaurants led by the three-Michelin-star chefs FrÃ©dÃ©ric Anton and Alain Ducasse.

For a more intimate experience, go for the [Don Juan II](https://donjuan2.yachtsdeparis.fr/en), overseen by FrÃ©dÃ©ric Anton. Belonging to the [Yachts de Paris](https://www.yachtsdeparis.fr/), the restaurant only has a handful of tables but has itself earned a Michelin star under Anton's leadership. Inside, mahogany paneling, thick carpets, and opulent Pierre Frey fabrics give the space a homely feel. The boat leaves at sundown, and guests get to gaze out at Parisâ most magical highlights, from Notre Dame Cathedral to the Eiffel Tower lit by hundreds of little lights, as they tuck into a five-course seasonal menu, with highlights such as creamy stracciatella with lashings of caviar, and fleshy langoustine.

The other, livelier option is a table on board the shiny steel-and-glass [Ducasse sur Seine](https://www.ducasse-seine.com/fr), which takes the same route and serves four- to six-course menus designed in conjunction with Alain Ducasse.

You can go up on deck on both boats, which is the best spot for watching the Eiffel Tower dazzle on the hour.

**Planning tip:** Do make reservations as far in advance as possible as both dinner cruises tend to get booked up. The ports can be tricky to find, especially when youâre not familiar with the quays, so allow for plenty of time to arrive because the cruises won't wait.

## 2. Enjoy a picnic with a view of Notre Dame

[Notre Dame Cathedral](https://www.notredamedeparis.fr/en/) is (rightfully) a major highlight in all the guidebooks, but it has become a victim of overtourism. The interiors are beautiful, but if you don't want to queue up to visit, you can see it from a different perspective instead.

Pack a picnic â perhaps a baguette, salted butter, ham and cheeses â and set up on the small stretch of the Seine riverbank west of the Port de Montebello. From here, you can see the cathedralâs wooden lattice structure known as the âforestâ because it was made using oak trees. Before the roof was destroyed in the 2019 fire, it was one of the oldest frameworks in Paris. The 16 statues of the Apostles and Evangelists, which were staggered on the roof of the cathedral, eerily looking down from above, were spared from the fire and are now back.

**Planning tip:** As with any outdoor activity, make sure to check the weather conditions before you put together your picnic and set off.

![Fresh pastries at Boulangerie Utopie in Paris.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-01/Pastries-at-Boulangerie-Utopie.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

## 3. Renew your appreciation for croissants

Croissants might be an everyday staple in France, but the painstaking work that goes into making the buttery *viennoiseries* (sweet baked goods) is sometimes taken for granted. However, after taking a croissant-making class at the Seine-side [La Cuisine Paris cooking school](https://lacuisineparis.com/), I learned that it takes several days to make croissants. They have no less than 81 layers of pastry and butter that are lovingly kneaded, delicately rolled together and plaited before they can go in the oven. That was just one of many interesting facts we learned from taking the class, making it a novel way of getting to know about French food and culture.

**Planning tip:** Book in advance as the classes are very popular. La Cuisine also does gift vouchers, which could make good presents for friends and family traveling to Paris in the near future.

## 4. Dive into Parisâ contemporary art scene with your own guide

Swap Parisâ overcrowded museums for some gallery hopping across the city, from the chic Marais to bohemian Belleville. Itâs here that youâll catch much of the art sceneâs latest emerging talent and you wonât need to queue â in fact youâll often get the chance to be alone in a room to take in the works. If youâre lucky, you might even get to meet the artists as they stop by to check in on their show.

If you donât know where to start, get in touch with Paris [art guide Alexandra Weinress](https://www.theseenparis.com/about), who will take you on a tailor-made tour in English or French, based on your interests. She can also include fun pit stops like a lunch at one of her favorite modern brasseries.

## 5. Explore a mass grave below ground

First and foremost, a word of warning that this isnât for the fainthearted. But head 20m (66ft) below ground, and you'll enter the maze of galleries that make up the [Catacombs of Paris](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/montparnasse-and-southern-paris/attractions/les-catacombes/a/poi-sig/372143/1323144), containing the remains of several million Parisians. During the 18th century, the rise in public health risks linked to the cityâs cemeteries led to bones and skulls being exhumed and transferred here, arranged several meters high along the walls in underground galleries. Today, you can listen to an audio guide of the giant tomb, which brings to light yet another fascinating and offbeat part of Parisian history.

**Planning tip:** Be warned that the Catacombs are accessible via stairs only, including on the way out, which may not be suitable for some visitors.

![PARIS, FRANCE - MAY 30, 2015: View of famous Louvre Museum from the Seine River.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-03/Shutterstock402954385.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

## 6. Visit the largest museum on Earth

If you guessed the [MuseÃ© du Louvre](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/louvre-and-les-halles/attractions/musee-du-louvre/a/poi-sig/372123/1322719), then you guessed right. Yes, it may be firmly on the well-beaten tourist track, but itâs there for good reason, one being its size. Once the royal palace that housed none other than Napoleon, the Louvre has borne witness to centuries of history since it was founded in 1793. The largest museum in the world, it has almost 73,000 sq meters (785,765 sq ft) of exhibition space, 403 rooms, and 14.5km (9 miles) of corridors, where 33,000 artworks out of nearly 500,000 held by the museum are showcased. The works span several thousand years and continents, from the Americas to Asia, with the Egyptian wing being a favorite.

Head-spinning facts aside, for visitors who arenât fans of the museum experience, itâs also possible to get a sense of the Louvreâs size, importance, and beauty by walking the full length of its exterior from the rue de Rivoli to its interior courtyards, which are [accessible for free](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/top-free-things-to-do-in-paris) throughout the day.

**Planning tip:** The museum is open until 9pm on Wednesdays and Fridays, when it tends to be less crowded. Like many museums in Paris, the Louvre is closed on Tuesdays. Check the latest timings on the [Louvre website](https://www.louvre.fr/en) beforehand, as they can vary from season to season.

![The Place du Tertre with tables of cafe and the Sacre-Coeur in the morning, quarter Montmartre in Paris](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-03/GettyImages-1097395338.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

## 7. Travel back in time to bohemian Montmartre

[Montmartre](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/montmartre-and-northern-paris) is a village with bohemian artistic roots. Perched on the highest hill of Paris, it's crowned by the gleaming white [SacrÃ©-Coeur Basilica](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/montmartre-and-northern-paris/attractions/basilique-du-sacre-coeur/a/poi-sig/372145/1323143), which opened in 1910. One of the last villages to join [the arrondissements of Paris](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/guide-paris-arrondissements) proper, it has retained its village atmosphere, with narrow lanes that wind down the hillsides, lined with stone houses, cafes, restaurants, and boutiques. This was once a stomping ground for artists including Pablo Picasso, who would hole up at [Le Bateau Lavoir](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/montmartre-and-northern-paris/attractions/le-bateau-lavoir/a/poi-sig/1193707/1323143) â an artistsâ residency that to this day seldom opens its doors to visitors â and party at the numerous nightlife spots.

The village was scattered with windmills that once ground flour and crushed grapes, giving rise to debauched nights in the areaâs cabarets and guinguettes (popular outdoor taverns where there is dancing). Some of these have survived, like [Chez Michou](https://www.michou.com/) and [Le Lapin Agile](https://au-lapin-agile.com/en/accueil-english/). Today, there is only one functioning windmill left, the [Blute-Fin windmill](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/montmartre-and-northern-paris/attractions/moulin-blute-fin/a/poi-sig/1262484/1323143), which is not accessible to the public. The [Radet windmill](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/montmartre-and-northern-paris/attractions/moulin-radet/a/poi-sig/1262480/1323143) you see as part of the [Moulin de la Galette](https://www.moulindelagaletteparis.com/en/) restaurant on rue Lepic once stood next to the Blute-Fin and was moved here in the 1920s. The [Clos Montmartre](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/montmartre-and-northern-paris/attractions/clos-montmartre/a/poi-sig/1262485/1323143) vineyard still exists and there is an annual grape harvest festival in October, which is worth coming to the city for.

**Planning tip:** The best way to see Montmartre is by taking one of our itineraries in the latest [Lonely Planet Paris guidebook](https://shop.lonelyplanet.com/products/paris). Alternatively, take the [Promotrain](https://promotrain.fr/?lang=en) or [Montmartrain](https://www.lemontmartrain.fr/), which carry visitors around Montmartre to the main sites. Itâs about an hour round trip, and they're especially good for people with restricted mobility, families with young children, and visitors short on time.

## 8. Soak up the magic of the Latin Quarter at sundown

The [Latin Quarter](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/the-latin-quarter) is one of Parisâ oldest districts, with some parts dating back to Roman and Medieval times. Some vestiges from the Roman period are still visible to this day, like the [ArÃ¨nes de LutÃ¨ce](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/the-latin-quarter/attractions/arenes-de-lutece/a/poi-sig/372591/1322729), a former amphitheater, and the baths inside the Cluny Museum; and from the Middle Ages too, such as the [Church of Saint SÃ©verin](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/the-latin-quarter/attractions/eglise-st-severin/a/poi-sig/1272513/1322729) as well as [La Sorbonne](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/the-latin-quarter/attractions/sorbonne/a/poi-sig/1264244/1322729) university, founded in 1253.

While the Latin Quarter is one of the most atmospheric areas of the city, itâs also one of the busiest. A way around that is to visit at sundown, when most visitors go back to their accommodations. One of the highlights of Paris in general is strolling at nightfall because the buildings are lit up in such a way that it brings out lots of small details you might miss in the daytime. The Latin Quarter is no exception. Stop at the [Bombardier](https://www.bombardierpub.fr/) pub for a drink on the terrace, right across from the regal [PanthÃ©on](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/the-latin-quarter/attractions/pantheon/a/poi-sig/1264241/1322729), where some of the countryâs greatest thinkers have been laid to rest, including Simone Veil and Victor Hugo.

## 9. Get under the surface of Franceâs food scene

France's food scene is a major draw for visitors, and in Paris there are over 80 fresh produce markets, hundreds of delis and bakeries, and thousands of restaurants and cafes to try. To really understand the localsâ love of food, the history behind its national importance, and to taste some local favorites too, book a tour with a guide.

Food guide Neil Kreeger ([neil.kreeger@gmail.com](mailto:neil.kreeger@gmail.com)) puts together bespoke itineraries based on your preferences and unpacks the mysteries behind every major French classic, from macarons and croque monsieur to the numerous cheeses and wines, as well as the more recent food trends. Experiences last about three hours in one neighborhood.

![A white marble statue of an angel on the tomb of composer Frederic Chopin at PÃ¨re-Lachaise Cemetery in Paris](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2024-06/GettyImages-499364569.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

## 10. Ponder the lives of luminaries departed

A great way of seeing another side of Paris is through some of its beautiful cemeteries. The most famous is [PÃ¨re-Lachaise](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/marais-and-menilmontant/attractions/cimetiere-du-pere-lachaise/a/poi-sig/372157/1322812) in the 20th arrondissement, which spans 44 hectares (108 acres) and contains no less than 70,000 burial plots. Created in 1804, itâs halfway between a leafy park and a huge shrine, where the style of the graves ranges from Gothic mini chapels to impressive Haussmannian burial chambers and great big mausoleums for whole families.

Some of the cemeteryâs most famous âresidentsâ include Oscar Wilde, MoliÃ¨re, Edith Piaf, FrÃ©dÃ©ric Chopin and Jim Morrison, whose graves are popular tourist spots for visitors from all over the world â three million a year descend on the cemetery, to be exact.

## 11. Find your favorite view of the Eiffel Tower

Of course, itâs obvious that Paris is the only place you can see the [Eiffel Tower](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/eiffel-tower-16e-and-la-defense/attractions/eiffel-tower/a/poi-sig/372147/1322674). But whereâs the best vantage point? Thatâs the million-dollar question that could keep locals debating all night long. Catching glimpses of the Grande Dame from all over the city is half the fun. For visitors who want the real, full-size, unobstructed view, then the Trocadero is the number one spot. For a 360-degree view from the skies, then the [Montparnasse Tower](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/montparnasse-and-southern-paris/attractions/tour-montparnasse/a/poi-sig/372335/1323144) rooftop observation deck has to be it. And for more fleeting glimpses, [catch the metro](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/getting-around-paris) line 6 between the stops of Passy and Bir-Hakeim. Otherwise, there are several rooftop restaurants and bars where you can dine while gazing at Parisâ most popular monument, like at Le Printemps and Galeries Lafayette department stores, and many five-star hotel rooftop restaurants like the Peninsulaâs [LâOiseau Blanc](https://www.peninsula.com/en/paris/hotel-fine-dining/french-rooftop-loiseau-blanc), the Cheval Blancâs [Tout-Paris](https://www.chevalblanc.com/en/maison/paris/restaurants-and-bars/le-tout-paris/) or [Le Jardin](https://www.chevalblanc.com/en/maison/paris/restaurants-and-bars/le-jardin-de-cheval-blanc-paris/), or the [Shangri-La](https://www.shangri-la.com/en/paris/shangrila)âs champagne garden in summer.

![\An interior view of Opera de Paris, Palais Garnier](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-03/Shutterstock2136298843.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

## 12. Resurrect the Phantom of the Opera

You can book to see a show at the [Palais Garnier](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/champs-elysees-and-grands-boulevards/attractions/palais-garnier/a/poi-sig/1237258/1322783), Parisâ world-famous opera house. Built in 1875, it was named after Charles Garnier, its architect. Itâs an Italian-style auditorium known for its celestial ceiling fresco by artist Marc Chagall, and can hold up to 2,054 visitors in one sitting. Possibly the most famous opera house in the world, it was immortalized in the novel The Phantom of the Opera, keeping the legend of terrifying ghostly happenings alive.

Itâs possible to visit the incredibly opulent opera house, with its heavily gilded interiors and grand marble staircases. You'll walk the maze-like corridors of dressing rooms and rehearsal spaces, behind and under the stage, and even see the underground lake that flows below the opera house.

**Planning tip:** There are a number of ways to [visit the opera house](https://www.operadeparis.fr/visites/palais-garnier), including self-guided visits, guided tours, through an immersive game based on the story of the 1905 fictional thief and master of disguise ArsÃ¨ne Lupin, and via games for children.

![Stalls inside the St-Ouen flea market (Porte de Clignancourt) in Paris.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2023-08/shutterstockRF252870904.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

## 13. Lose yourself in the worldâs biggest flea market

While it is true that most of Paris' blockbuster sights are found within the city center, itâs worth [venturing a little further afield](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/the-best-day-trips-from-paris) to visit St-Ouen flea market, the Puces de St-Ouen. One of the biggest markets in the world, itâs actually made up of 15 markets selling all sorts of wares, from antique jewelry to furniture, clothing and records. Hidden in the markets are also restaurants and cafes that make great pit stops to sit and watch life go by. Start on rue des Rosiers in St-Ouen, which isnât in Paris proper, and wander through the markets that sprawl out on either side in warehouse spaces. You could easily spend a whole day exploring.

Plan with a local

Experience the real France

Both banks are listed as UNESCO World Heritage Sites and each offer their own distinct flavor of the Parisian experience. The Left Bank has long been linked to writers, artists and cafe culture. Hemingway, Picasso and Matisse all once called La Rive Gauche their home. Grab an old-fashioned hot chocolate at Le Deux Magots, explore the winding alleyways of the Latin Quarter and browse the bouquinistes set up along the river, independent book vendors selling old books, [...] Hop on a river cruise or stroll alongside this famous waterway—it flows through the heart of Paris and separates the city's left and right banks.

At the same time, the Catholic church proclaimed a rebirth of Notre Dame, 2025 Jubilee, a special year to offer a time of grace, forgiveness and spiritual renewal, a tradition that dates to 1300. Located on the eastern half of Ile de la Cite, an island in the Seine River, Notre Dame is one of the oldest cathedrals in the world, combining elements of Gothic and Romanesque styles. It is a shining example of architectural genius and artistic spirit. Construction began in 1163 and largely completed in 1345. It was modified in the 13th century, restored in the 19th century and restored again in 2019-2024. The cathedral is 420 feet long and 157 feet wide with a spire height of 315 feet. It features breathtaking stained glass windows, elaborate stone carvings and soaring spires which reach heights of 100 meters. In the wake of the first, only one of the cathedral's three great rose windows retains its original 13th century glass. Notre Dame also houses numerous significant religious and historical artifacts, including the Crown of Thorns, believed to have been worn by Jesus Christ during his crucifixion. Open from 7:50 to 7 Monday through Friday, to 10 on Thursday, and 8:15 to 7:30 on Saturday and Sunday, Notre Dame is visited by more than 12 million people each year. Not much time is required to spend here, unless you decide to buy a ticket to the top of the arc, but I don't personally believe it is necessary to enjoy the experience. Instead, circling around the monument, observing its inner carvings and intricate sculptures are simple yet interesting actiond that will teach you several things about the events of which the monument provides homage to. Around 30 minutes to an hour is enough to enjoy this, and its relatively easy to navigate to considering it is right next to champs elysees and is the center of an intersection, where several metro stations and bus stops can be found. *   [![Image 251](https://dynamic-media-cdn.tripadvisor.com/media/photo-f/01/2e/70/7f/avatar066.jpg?w=100&h=-1&s=1)](https://www.tripadvisor.com/ClientLink?value=OGZQXy9Qcm9maWxlLzg2NlRheWxvckJfaXJt)      [Taylor B](https://www.tripadvisor.com/ClientLink?value=OGZQXy9Qcm9maWxlLzg2NlRheWxvckJfaXJt)Chicago, IL 8,857 contributions    0        [Recalling Gene Kelly, an American in Paris](https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowUserReviews-g187147-d189284-r1017365743-Montmartre-Paris_Ile_de_France.html) Montmartre is the Paris that we came to see, the whimsical, charming neighborhood that Gene Kelly experienced in the Oscar-winning 1951 musical An American in Paris. It sits atop a hill, the highest point in the city. It is one of the best sections to walk around in. You'll find street artists, historic monuments and quaint cafes. And you're close to the one and only Moulin Rouge. Start with the Basilica of the Sacred Heart of Paris, arguably the most beautiful church in the city. Including the more celebrated Notre Dame. Climb the 300 steps to the top of the dome and enjoy the most panoramic view of the city, notwithstanding the Eiffel Tower. Adjacent to the basilica is a green space called Square Louise-Michel, a great spot for a picnic. At the bottom of the hill lies the indescribable I Love You Wall at Square Jehan-Rictus, an art piece that includes "I love you" written 311 times in 250 languages. For drinks, stop at the Cafe des Deux Moulins. For breakfast, the Hardware Societe on Rue Lamarck is recommended. For a cup of coffee, visit the Spree cafe and art gallery on Rue la Vieuville. Aside from the Basilica of the Sacred Heart, the district is known as an art hotspot where Picasso, van Gogh and Renoir were among the painters who once lived and worked in Montmartre. If you're looking for a rendition of the famous "can-can" dance, the Moulin Rouge cabaret is on Boulevard de Clichy, on the outskirts of the Montmartre neighborhood. The district also features several museums, including the Salvador Dali Museum with 300 works of the surrealist artist, the Montmartre Museum that showcases the district's history through paintings, sculptures and posters, and the Museum of Romantic Life. The Pere Lachaise is the most celebrated cemetery in Paris, the final resting place for Oscar Wilde and Jim Morrison, but the Cemetary of Montmartre also attracts a crowd. Among 20,000 burial plots is Emile Zola. For trivia buffs, Montmartre is home to the oldest pedestrian street in Paris, the Rue Saint-Rustique. *   [![Image 252](https://dynamic-media-cdn.tripadvisor.com/media/photo-f/01/2e/70/7f/avatar066.jpg?w=100&h=-1&s=1)](https://www.tripadvisor.com/ClientLink?value=OGZQXy9Qcm9maWxlLzg2NlRheWxvckJfaXJt)      [Taylor B](https://www.tripadvisor.com/ClientLink?value=OGZQXy9Qcm9maWxlLzg2NlRheWxvckJfaXJt)Chicago, IL 8,857 contributions    0        [Which side of the Seine do you prefer?](https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowUserReviews-g187147-d189683-r1017314094-Seine_River-Paris_Ile_de_France.html) The Seine River is to Paris what the Thames is to London, what the Mississippi is to New Orleans, what the Nile is to Cairo. Cutting through the very heart of Paris, it is the epicenter of the vibrant French capital. The gentle waterway is an integral part of the city and its fascinating history. The two banks of the Seine are referred to as La Rive Gauche (the Left Bank) and a La Rive Droite (the Right Bank). Both banks are listed as UNESCO World Heritage Sites and each offer their own distinct flavor of the Parisian experience. The Left Bank has long been linked to writers, artists and cafe culture. Hemingway, Picasso and Matisse all once called La Rive Gauche their home. Grab an old-fashioned hot chocolate at Le Deux Magots, explore the winding alleyways of the Latin Quarter and browse the bouquinistes set up along the river, independent book vendors selling old books, magazines and collectibles from iconic green metal boxes. Meanwhile, the Right Bank has always had stronger links with commerce and trade, the wealthier side of the Seine. It also lays claim to many of Paris' most notable attractions, including the Louvre Museum, Notre Dame Cathedral, the Eiffel Tower and the Arc de Triomphe. Over a dozen historic bridges connect the Left and Right bank of the Seine as the river snakes through the heart of Paris, most notably the Pont Neuf, Pont Alexander 111 and Pont des Arts. For a relaxing way to take in all the best views from the Seine, a two-hour riverboat tour is highly recommended. *   [![Image 254](https://dynamic-media-cdn.tripadvisor.com/media/photo-f/01/2e/70/7f/avatar066.jpg?w=100&h=-1&s=1)](https://www.tripadvisor.com/ClientLink?value=OGZQXy9Qcm9maWxlLzg2NlRheWxvckJfaXJt)      [Taylor B](https://www.tripadvisor.com/ClientLink?value=OGZQXy9Qcm9maWxlLzg2NlRheWxvckJfaXJt)Chicago, IL 8,857 contributions    0        [The Paris neighborhood with so much to offer](https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowUserReviews-g187147-d292257-r1017678632-Le_Marais-Paris_Ile_de_France.html) Le Marais is a romantic and festive neighborhood in central Paris that has so much to offer with its cobblestone streets, small boutiques and historic places. Bounded by the Place de la Bastille to the west, the Right Bank of the Seine River to the south and the Place de la Republique to the north, it features many art galleries and museums, restaurants, bars, bakeries, night clubs and 17th century hotels with their carved white ashlars and wide porches. Where to begin? The majestic Hotel Sale, where the writer Honore de Balzac once sat and which today houses the famous Picasso Museum with more than 5,000 works by the Spanish artist. The Place des Vosges, the oldest square in Paris. The architecturally imposing Hotel de Ville. On rue Montmorency is the half-timbered house of Nicolas Flamel, which was built in 1407. Visit the Baroque church of Saint-Louis Saint Paul with its colorful clock and painting by Eugene Delacroix. The George Pompidou Centre is home to France's largest collection of modern and contemporary art. The Galerie Perrotin is the most celebrated art gallery in Paris. See the musee Cognacz-Jay, a Parisian mansion from the Age of Enlightenment, and the Musee Carnavalet with memorabilia from the French Revolution. The house of writer Victor Hugo, which has been preserved as it was when the author of Les Miserables was alive. The Musee of Jewish Art and History is located in the Hotel de Saint-Aigan. For fashion lovers, Le Marais is one of the best areas for shoppers. BHV Marais dates to 1856. Other go-to destinations are Empreintes, Gucci, Karl Langerfeld and John Galliano. Tired? Need a break? The district features such noted restaurants as Glou, Robert et Louise, Brasserie Bofinger, Le Bel Canto and L'Ambroisie. And bakeries operated by gourmet pastry chefs such as Pierre Herme, Yann Courveur and Christophe Michalak. On the rue de Bretogne is the oldest street market in Paris, Marche Couvert des Enfants Rouges, with its colorful stalls, fresh produce, flowers and small dishes. *   [![Image 255](https://dynamic-media-cdn.tripadvisor.com/media/photo-f/01/2e/70/7f/avatar066.jpg?w=100&h=-1&s=1)](https://www.tripadvisor.com/ClientLink?value=OGZQXy9Qcm9maWxlLzg2NlRheWxvckJfaXJt)      [Taylor B](https://www.tripadvisor.com/ClientLink?value=OGZQXy9Qcm9maWxlLzg2NlRheWxvckJfaXJt)Chicago, IL 8,857 contributions    0        [Jewel of the radiant Gothic style](https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowUserReviews-g187147-d190202-r1017551630-Sainte_Chapelle-Paris_Ile_de_France.html) No matter how many historical sites you visit in Paris, from the Louvre to Notre Dame to the Orsay Museum to Versailles, you will come away awestruck by the 1,113 stained glass windows in the Saint-Chapelle. Located in the heart of the city on the Ile de la Cite, it was built in the middle of the 13th century by King Louis 1X to house the most prestigious relics of the Passion of Christ--the Crown of Thorns and a fragment of the True Cross. The Crown of Thorns was moved to Notre Dame on 1806. The 1,113 stained glass windows relate scenes of the Old and New Testaments and tell the story of the world, according to the Bible. Two-thirds of the windows are original. Visitors are awed by 15 exceptional windows of breathtaking dimensions, 15 meters high in the nave and 13 meters high in the choir. Acquisition of the famous relics and construction of Sainte-Chapelle increased the prestige of France. Paris became, in the eyes of medieval Europe, a "new Jerusalem" and thus the beacon of Western Christianity. The building consists of an upper level, the upper chapel in which the relics of the Passion of Christ are exalted, and the lower chapel serving the palace staff. The spire rises to 75 meters above the ground. The church is open to the public daily from 9 to 7 but it hasn't been used for worship since the French Revolution. However, the monument still shines today as one of the most extraordinary masterpieces of the High Gothic style. One warning: Sainte-Chapelle isn't air conditioned. Art Museums in Paris

THE 15 BEST Paris Art Museums
=============================

Art Museums in Paris
====================

The Mona Lisa is a masterpiece for a reason, and getting some face time with one of the world’s best-known faces is worth the effort. Though it really is an effort, usually requiring a relay race through the Louvre’s famously long lines. Lines are almost as long at other top museums like Musee d’Orsay. We can’t magically scoot you to the front, but we can help you avoid the worst of it. To start, buy timed tickets a couple of months in advance. Consider booking a tour with skip-the-line-access. And line up a guide that knows the best routes through each museum so you can see the most in the least amount of time.

Four years in renovations to hide elevators.

Go across the street to a free true art exhibit. After 4 1/2 hours, we spent 1/2 hour getting out! We saw some of the things we wanted to see, but some things we saw 3 times while trying to get out of an area to another section. (And we asked MANY times for directions.) Tripadvisor performs checks on reviews.      
*   [![Image 24](https://dynamic-media-cdn.tripadvisor.com/media/photo-o/04/08/2f/fd/brad-b.jpg?w=100&h=-1&s=1)](https://www.tripadvisor.com/ClientLink?value=MkY5Xy9Qcm9maWxlL2JyYWRiNTIyX0JOYQ%3D%3D)      [Brad B](https://www.tripadvisor.com/ClientLink?value=MkY5Xy9Qcm9maWxlL2JyYWRiNTIyX0JOYQ%3D%3D)Joliet, IL 7 contributions    1        [The Best Part Of My Paris Trip](https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowUserReviews-g187147-d2213459-r232835313-Paris_Private_Guide_Esprit_De_Paris-Paris_Ile_de_France.html) I loved everything about Paris, but the best was Adeline. She was very knowledgable, kind, and fun! I loved all of our discussions about history, politics, culture, and family. Those talks took the trip to another level.

She's also a great little shopper. She arranged for a private boat with picnic to float down the Seine for six. She secured another guide for my friends who had never been to Paris. Her name was Flora and my friends loved her. I have been to Paris several times, but was able to see it in a totally new way, thanks to Adeline.

I would highly recommend her.
